review_title: Like with All Places, It's All About Your Manager
pros:
Hilton, by virtue of its pre-pandemic financial success and brand equity, has attracted some great people, especially in the rank and file and middle management (VPs and below...esp at the Director level).  

Chris Nassetta seems to be a good CEO. 

Generally strong work-life balance (again, pre-pandemic). 

Hospitality generally tends to attract people with good values, and it's one of the last industries that can survive in a country where AI and labor offshoring have reduced headcount needs.

The Development team is top notch. Their success is really what makes us go-go-go! 

Compensation is OK. They know that they're one of the only places in town with international brand recognition in a highly visible consumer industry, so they know they don't have to overpay to get good talent. 

Impressive gender diversity in senior leadership. It's really inspiring to see other women hold truly prominent positions of leadership.  

Good diversity in rank and file.

Nice facilities (though always cramped - most floors are open layout and seemed to get smaller and smaller over time as they squished us into nicer looking but more cramped spaces over time) and a well maintained physical working environment (at least, in a pre-pandemic world).
cons:
As great as some of the leadership is, leadership at the top levels are usually very political (par for the course in big orgs), and some are breathtakingly poor leaders. 

At this point, most don't have to read "Good to Great" to know that leadership is critical to strong organizations. Hilton has marginal leadership training and very little "culture" around building strong leaders. It's as if the focus is on marketing about how great the culture is vs. the hard work of actually training and holding people accountable to building a great culture. If you're a decent individual contributor and you're around long enough, you'll probably get the ability to manage others, even if you're incompetent at managing, and you'll pretty much get to do what you want. If you're lucky, you report to someone who has some innate leadership skill. If you're not, well...

Even when senior leaders are widely known to be poor, the organization tends to let them flounder and damage morale for a while before doing something about it (assuming that they do decide to act). That may or may not have to do with the mediocre Human Resources team, who can be expected to basically only do what HR teams at most average places do - protect the company from lawsuits at all costs. When it comes to anything beyond that wheelhouse, they are poorly equipped (just ask a few people about the mass confusion in process from pandemic-related layoffs). 

Almost no ethnic diversity in senior leadership.

Hilton is no better or worse than any other random big successful company, they just started buying their own press about how special they were after paying for the trademarks to claim themselves Fortune's Best Place to Work.

job_title: Director of Marketing in McLean, VA
pros: Hilton is one of the most recognized companies in the world.  A job there brings instant credibility and instant respect from your professional network and prospective employers.  The culture is generally supportive.  Colleagues work together in a constructive and collaborative way.  There are many opportunities to work on international projects and  learn how to conduct business on a global scale.  I learned a lot while I was working there.
cons: The company is not very family-friendly.  The people who get the most out of it are either very young--i.e. no children--have no children, or have older children--college age or older.  The work can be exciting but there is a LOT of it.  They run a lean operation over there and they're slow to add headcount as the workload increases.   This means logging lots of time at the office to get things done.  Also,while their global reach is a huge plus in many areas, it also means a lot of business travel to keep things going.  If you have small children and a spouse that works, it can get pretty crazy at home.  Meanwhile, their compensation, while nothing to sneeze at, doesn't go very far once you have to shell out for childcare every day.  Senior management likes to talk about how work-life balance and employee satisfaction is important to them, but I didn't see them taking many concrete actions to improve it.

pros:
Leadership/senior director level is full of studs. Visionaries who get it and care. 

Senior Manager/lower director level is mostly competent, experienced, and reasonable. A few bad eggs but most of them don't have direct reports. You are generally allowed to bite off as much as you want to chew, so long as your day-to-day is done well. 

Benefits are fantastic with plenty of PTO/holidays, a good match, and a solid choice of health plans. 

The work environment is the right level of casual. Working from home 1-2 days per week is no big deal.

The Go Hilton perk is fantastic, amounting to some $3k+ in hotel room savings annually if you play your cards right, and the Long Tenure program is an extremely nice carrot to encourage you to stay for a long time. 

Just lots of really nice, smart people.
cons:
Pay and raises are lower than expected and you will generally make more doing the exact same job at another company in most (corporate) roles.

There is definitely a disappointing "who you know" component to moving up, though it is less so than at other companies. "What you know" remains most important, but you will find many career Hiltoners (many of whom have near-irreplaceable knowledge) that have been stuck in tactical roles for many years that aren't commensurate with the amount of value they're bringing to Hilton.

review_title: One of the best companies I've ever worked for
pros:
I spent about 4 years total working for Hilton Hotels in Orlando, FL, both as a direct employee, then as a contracted concierge. Overall, it was a great experience and a wonderful company to work for.

Pros are as follows...

-Decent wages 

-Excellent PTO system

-With it being hospitality, expect to work a lot of weekends and major holidays. But in my experience, we got to choose which holidays were most important for us to have off, and we typically got the ones we wanted.

-Fun, friendly work environment. I met several of my closest friends from Hilton.

-Company is constantly growing and evolving, so there's always openings and opportunities for growth
cons:
The cons I experienced working for Hilton were mostly associated with my direct managers, so they can't really be applied to the company as a whole.

Management is almost always changing, as promotions are quite common. In the 2 years I spent in my first role with Hilton, I had about 7 different direct managers. Some I liked, and some weren't so great. I ultimately left that particular role and property with several other employees because the new manager was not working out for us. But again, that only pertains to that particular experience.

Also, be sure to fight for your annual raise. Each year, you are reviewed and "graded" on your job performance. Your raise is then a reflection of that score. If you don't agree with your scored, fight it and see that you get the raise you deserve.
